raw_text: Clark and Curran (2007) show that both accurate and highly efficient parsing is possible using a CCG
clean_text: Clark and Curran (2007) show that both accurate and highly efficient parsing is possible using a CCG.

raw_text: From a parsing perspective, the C& amp; C parser (Clark and Curran, 2007) has been shown to be competitive with state-of-theart statistical parsers on a variety of test suites, including those consisting of grammatical relations (Clark and Curran, 2007), Penn Treebank phrase structure trees (Clark and Curran, 2009), and unbounded dependencies (Rimell et al, 2009)
clean_text: From a parsing perspective, the C & C parser (Clark and Curran, 2007) has been shown to be competitive with state-of-theart statistical parsers on a variety of test suites, including those consisting of grammatical relations (Clark and Curran, 2007), Penn Treebank phrase structure trees (Clark and Curran, 2009), and unbounded dependencies (Rimell et al, 2009).

raw_text: However, the parsing work by Clark and Curran (2007), and also Hockenmaier (2003) and Fowler and Penn (2010), has only considered chart-parsing
clean_text: However, the parsing work by Clark and Curran (2007), and also Hockenmaier (2003) and Fowler and Penn (2010), has only considered chart-parsing.

raw_text: Following Clark and Curran (2007), we assume that each input word has been assigned a POS-tag (from the Penn Treebank tag set) and a set of CCG lexical categories
clean_text: Following Clark and Curran (2007), we assume that each input word has been assigned a POS-tag (from the Penn Treebank tag set) and a set of CCG lexical categories.

raw_text: Clark and Curran (2007) gives a more precise definition
clean_text: Clark and Curran (2007) gives a more precise definition.

raw_text: We ran the C& amp; C parser using the normal-form model (we reproduced the numbers reported in Clark and Cur ran (2007)), and copied the results of the hybrid model from Clark and Curran (2007), since the hybrid model is not part of the public release
clean_text: We ran the C & C parser using the normal-form model (we reproduced the numbers reported in Clark and Cur ran (2007)), and copied the results of the hybrid model from Clark and Curran (2007), since the hybrid model is not part of the public release.

raw_text: The numbers for C& amp; C are for the hybrid model, copied from Clark and Curran (2007)
clean_text: The numbers for C & C are for the hybrid model, copied from Clark and Curran (2007).

raw_text: The numbers for the normal-form model are evaluated by running the publicly available parser, while those for the hybrid dependency model are from Clark and Curran (2007)
clean_text: The numbers for the normal-form model are evaluated by running the publicly available parser, while those for the hybrid dependency model are from Clark and Curran (2007).

raw_text: For example, forward type-raising can change a subject NP into a complex category looking to the right for a verb phrase: NP? S/ (SNP) Following Hockenmaier (2003), we extract the grammar by reading rule instances directly from the derivations in CCGbank (Hockenmaier and Steed man, 2007), rather than defining the combinatory rule schema manually as in Clark and Curran (2007)
clean_text: Following Hockenmaier (2003), we extract the grammar by reading rule instances directly from the derivations in CCGbank (Hockenmaier and Steedman, 2007), rather than defining the combinatory rule schema manually as in Clark and Curran (2007).

raw_text: When it is reasonable to assume that the input sentence for the grammaticality improvement system is sufficiently fluent, a list of candidate lexical categories can be assigned automatically to each word via super tagging (Clark and Curran, 2007) on the input sequence
clean_text: When it is reasonable to assume that the input sentence for the grammaticality improvement system is sufficiently fluent, a list of candidate lexical categories can be assigned automatically to each word via super tagging (Clark and Curran, 2007) on the input sequence.

raw_text: The average number of lexical categories per word drops to 1.3 when? equals 0.075, which is the value used for parsing newspaper text in Clark and Curran (2007)
clean_text: The average number of lexical categories per word drops to 1.3 when equals 0.075, which is the value used for parsing newspaper text in Clark and Curran (2007).

raw_text: However, com pared to the 93% lexical category accuracy of a CCG parser (Clark and Curran, 2007), which also uses a? level of 0.075 for the majority of sentences, the ac curacy of our grammaticality improvement system is much lower
clean_text: However, compared to the 93% lexical category accuracy of a CCG parser (Clark and Curran, 2007), which also uses a level of 0.075 for the majority of sentences, the accuracy of our grammaticality improvement system is much lower.

raw_text: We parsed both corpora using the C& amp; C parser (Clark and Curran, 2007) as we employ both GRand POS information in our learning method
clean_text: We parsed both corpora using the C & C parser (Clark and Curran, 2007) as we employ both GR and POS information in our learning method.

raw_text: We compare the CCG parser of Clark and Curran (2007) with a state-of-the-art PennTreebank (PTB) parser
clean_text: We compare the CCG parser of Clark and Curran (2007) with a state-of-the-art PennTreebank (PTB) parser.

raw_text: Examples of this approach include Riezler et al (2002), Miyao and Tsujii (2005), Briscoe and Carroll (2006), and Clark and Curran (2007)
clean_text: Examples of this approach include Riezler et al (2002), Miyao and Tsujii (2005), Briscoe and Carroll (2006), and Clark and Curran (2007).

raw_text: The formalism-based parser we use is the CCG parser of Clark and Curran (2007) ,whichis based on CCGbank (Hockenmaier and Steed man, 2007), a CCG version of the Penn Treebank
clean_text: The formalism-based parser we use is the CCG parser of Clark and Curran (2007), which is based on CCGbank (Hockenmaier and Steedman, 2007), a CCG version of the Penn Treebank.

raw_text: The CCG parser has been extensively evaluated elsewhere (Clark and Curran, 2007), and arguably GRs or predicate-argument structures provide a more suitable test set for the CCG parser than PTB phrase-structure trees
clean_text: The CCG parser has been extensively evaluated elsewhere (Clark and Curran, 2007), and arguably GRs or predicate-argument structures provide a more suitable test set for the CCG parser than PTB phrase-structure trees.

raw_text: Theschemas were developed by manual inspection using section 00 of CCGbank and the PTBasa development set, following the oracle methodology of Clark and Curran (2007), in which gold standard derivations from CCGbank are converted to the new representation and compared with the gold standard for that representation
clean_text: The schemas were developed by manual inspection using section 00 of CCGbank and the PTB as a development set, following the oracle methodology of Clark and Curran (2007), in which gold standard derivations from CCGbank are converted to the new representation and compared with the gold standard for that representation.

raw_text: While high quality syntactic parsers are able to efficiently annotate large quantities of English text (Clark and Curran, 2007), existing approaches to query do not work on the same scale
clean_text: While high quality syntactic parsers are able to efficiently annotate large quantities of English text (Clark and Curran, 2007), existing approaches to query do not work on the same scale.
